NiGa alloy particles supported on CeO2, ZrO2 and ZrO2-CeO2 solid solutions are prepared, characterized, and utilized for hydrogenation of CO2 into methanol. The nature of the support, including the Zr:Ce ratio, affects the catalyst structure and properties such as the ZrO2 crystalline phase, number of basic sites and concentration of oxygen vacancies. At high Zr:Ce ratios, the crystalline structure of ZrO2 has more influence on the catalytic activity than the oxygen vacancies introduced by the addition of CeO2, with the pure ZrO2 having the highest methanol selectivity of 53% with a CO2 conversion of 2.1% at 260 °C and 600 psi. In the equimolar and Ce-rich catalysts with a tetragonal ZrO2 crystalline phase, basic sites, and oxygen vacancies are the parameters most influencing the methanol production. The highest methanol productivity was obtained for the Zr5Ce5 supported catalyst, with a selectivity of 46.8% and a CO2 conversion of 2.7%. Overall, the space time yield of methanol is shown to correlate linearly with the concentration of moderate basic sites. The catalysts possess low activity relative to comparable systems utilizing metallic Cu phases, in part due to low NiGa dispersions achieved using the synthetic methods employed here. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Methanol NiGa alloy Zr-Ce solid solutions Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) reports in their Sixth Assessment Report (AR6) an increase of 1.1 °C in the global surface temperature in 2020 relative to 1900, and an atmospheric concentration of CO2 of 410 ppm. This increase in temperature and CO2 emissions is already affecting the climate conditions and more frequent extreme heat events, floodings, droughts, among others, have occurred in the past decade. To avoid harsher and irreversible damage of global ecosystems, the global temperature increase needs to be limited to 1.5 °C by 2100 which means reaching net-zero CO2 emissions by 2050 [1]. Considering the existing infrastructure to process and transport C-based fuels and products, it has been proposed to shift to a carbon circular economy. In this model, C-based products are produced from CO2 emissions, instead of using fossil fuels [2,3]. This approach can help mitigating CO2 emissions, while fulfilling the C-based products demand. One of the routes that have gained interest for CO2 utilization is its hydrogenation to syngas, methane (CH4) [4,5] or methanol (MeOH),[6,7] or other high-volume products [8–11] using renewable H2 generated from water electrolysis using renewable energy. Among them, MeOH has special relevance since it is an intermediate molecule to produce formaldehyde, acetic acid, methyl tert-butyl ether, methyl methacrylate, olefins, aromatics, and other products of high relevance in several industries. Moreover, MeOH can be used as an additive for fuels due to its high-octane rating, or for electricity production in direct methanol oxidation fuel cells (DMFC) [11,12]. Currently, MeOH is synthesized from CO, obtained from the dry reforming of methane or coal gasification, using a Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst at high pressures (50 −100 bar) (Eq. 1). However, the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst suffers from deactivation due to sintering and poisoning from H2O adsorption. Moreover, when using CO2 as the carbon source, MeOH selectivity decreases due to the formation of CO or CH4, through reverse water gas shift (RWGS) (Eq. 2) or methanation reactions (Eq. 3), which are thermodynamically more favored. Another challenge for CO2 hydrogenation to MeOH (Eq. 4), is the activation of CO2. Since it is a highly stable molecule, high temperatures are required, which in turn promotes the endothermic RWGS [13]. Thus, in recent years research has focused on developing new catalytic systems that have high MeOH selectivity at low and moderate pressures (1–40 bar), inhibit the RWGS reaction, inhibit water adsorption on the active sites or improve the Cu-based catalyst[13–16]. Moreover, many publications explore the reaction mechanism [17], the effect of the reaction conditions [18], have developed kinetic models [19], or explored the catalyst properties that influence the performance [20–22] with the aim of rationalizing the design of new catalytic systems. (1) CO + 2 H 2 ↔ C H 3 OH ∆ H ° = − 90.6 kJ mol ∆ G ° = − 29.1 kJ mol (2) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O ∆ H ° = 41.2 kJ mol ∆ G ° = − 20.1 kJ mol (3) C O 2 + 4 H 2 ↔ C H 4 + 2 H 2 O ∆ H ° = − 252.9 kJ mol ∆ G ° = − 130.8 kJ mol (4) C O 2 + 3 H 2 ↔ C H 3 OH + H 2 O ∆ H ° = − 49.5 kJ mol ∆ G ° = − 9.0 kJ mol Among the new proposed catalytic systems, intermetallic alloys have gained interest due to tunable geometric and electronic properties [14,15]. In 2014, Studt et al. proposed through DFT calculations a new bimetallic NiGa catalyst active for CO2 hydrogenation at atmospheric pressure [23]. The synthesized NiGa/SiO2 catalysts exhibited a higher MeOH space time yield (STY) (0.25 mol MeOH/mol active metal /h) than that obtained for the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 (0.20 mol MeOH/mol active metal/h) catalyst at 200 °C and 1 bar. So far, the NiGa alloy system has been mainly studied using non-reducible SiO2 as the support, which has exhibited low MeOH yield due to low CO2 conversion (<1%) [23–25]. To overcome this, Rasteiro et al. evaluated the use of reducible metal oxides as supports for the NiGa alloy [26]. They reported a superior MeOH selectivity of 20% when using ZrO2 as the support and related it to the presence of oxygen vacancies (Ov) observed by ex situ XPS analysis of the reduced NiGa/ZrO2 catalyst. However, further increase in Ov content, using CeO2, resulted in low MeOH selectivity (3%), but with higher CO2 conversion (7%). For the Cu-based catalyst, a strategy that has been explored in the literature to improve its performance for CO2 hydrogenation to MeOH is the use of supports with abundant Ov that can activate CO2 [13,27]. CeO2 is known for its high oxygen storage capacity and excellent redox properties. However, it has been demonstrated that Ce3+ is easily oxidized at high temperature under a CO2 atmosphere [27,28]. To overcome these drawbacks, it has been reported that the addition of ZrO2 results in higher thermal stability, good Ov content due to formation of solid solutions, and higher catalyst stability due to its weak hydrophilic character that limits H2O adsorption [13,27,28]. Thus, different authors have reported an increase in MeOH selectivity and CO2 conversion when using ZrxCe1−xO solid solutions to tune the Ov content and improve Cu-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to MeOH [27,29–33]. In the case of Cu-based catalysts, literature has established the importance of metal-support interactions during CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. However, for the NiGa alloy system there are few reports on the role of metal-support interactions and the NiGa catalyst has been mainly studied over the non-reducible SiO2 support. Thus, seeking to understand how to tune the performance of NiGa alloy catalysts, in this work, we evaluate the effect of the Zr:Ce molar ratio on catalyst properties such basic sites, metal dispersion and oxygen vacancies, estimated from CO2-TPD, CO-chemisorption and XPS analysis. Then the relation between the catalysts’ properties on MeOH selectivity and CO2 conversion over a family of Ni5Ga3/ZrxCey catalysts is analyzed. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of ZrO2-CeO2 supports (labeled as ZrxCey, where x and y represent the Zr and Ce mol%, respectively) with different Zr:Ce molar ratios (1:0, 7:3, 5:5, 3:7, and 0:1) was prepared by co-precipitation. Taking Zr5Ce5 as an example, the synthesis was carried out as follows: 3 g of Zr(NO3)2·xH2O and 3.2 g of Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O (MilliporeSigma) were dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water. Then, the solution was heated to 70 °C with vigorous stirring (500 rpm). Next, 3.06 g of (NH4)2CO3 (MilliporeSigma) was dissolved in 100 mL deionized water as precipitant, and added dropwise to the Zr-Ce solution under vigorous stirring at 70 °C. The resulting suspension was aged for 2 h at 70 °C. After cooling to room temperature, the precipitate was recovered by filtration, washed 3 times with deionized water, and dried overnight at 105 °C. Finally, the supports were calcined in static air at 500 °C for 5 h (5 °C/min). Then, 20 wt% NiGa/ZrxCey samples were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation. An aqueous solution of Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O and Ga(NO3)3·xH2O with a Ni:Ga molar ratio of 5:3 was added dropwise to the ZrxCey support. The catalysts were dried at 105 °C overnight, calcined in static air at 400 °C for 4 h, reduced at 700 °C for 3 h using 10% H2/Ar (5 °C/min ramp rate), and passivated at room temperature using 1% O2/Ar. Finally, the powder catalysts were pelletized at 1000 psi to form pellets, and then crushed and sieved between 125 and 425 µm in size. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Pulse CO chemisorption, CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) and H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were performed using an Autochem II 2920 (Micromeritics, USA) equipped with a TCD detector. For CO-chemisorption and CO2-TPD, about 100 mg of the reduced powder catalyst was loaded in a U-shaped quartz tube. For CO chemisorption and CO2-TPD the catalyst was reduced at 400 °C for 2 h in 10% H2/Ar prior to analysis. The sample was then purged with He at 400 °C for 1 h and cooled to 40 °C. Pulses of 10% CO/He were introduced to the sample repeatedly until the TCD peak signal remained constant between pulses. For CO2-TPD, the catalyst was treated with CO2 for 60 min and then flushed by He until a stable baseline was obtained. Then the temperature was ramped from 40° to 600°C at 5 °C/min and the desorbed CO2 was detected using the TCD. For H2-TPR, the calcined catalyst was loaded to a U-shaped quartz tube, dried in He at 150 °C for 2 h, and then cooled to 40 °C. Finally, the sample was reduced in 10% H2/Ar and heated at 5 °C/min to 800 °C. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of the calcined supports and the reduced and pelletized catalysts was determined by N2 physisorption performed on a Tristar II 3020 (Micromeritics) at 77 K using ∼200 mg of sorbent. Samples were degassed under vacuum at 150 °C for 3 h prior to measurements. X-ray Powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the as-prepared supports and the reduced and passivated catalysts were recorded at room temperature on a PANalytical XPert PRO Alpha-1 (Malvern Panalytical) diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation in the 2θ range from 20° to 60°. Rietveld refinement was performed using the PANaytical software package HighScore using a polynomial function for the background determination, a pseudo-Voight profile function and Caglioti function for the FWHM. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis were conducted on an aberration-corrected Hitachi HD2700 (Hitachi High-Tech Corporation), equipped with a Bruker SDD EDS detector. Calcined and reduced samples were prepared by sonicating the catalyst in isopropyl alcohol, then adding a few drops of the solution onto holey carbon-coated Cu grids. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of the reduced and passivated powder samples was performed using a K-Alpha XPS System (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The data were collected under ultra-high vacuum using a monochromatic Al Kα radiation. A beam size of 400 µm, dwell time of 50 ms, and passing energy of 200 eV for the XPS survey and 50 eV for the high-resolution spectra of Ni2p, Ga2d, Zr3d, Ce3d, O1s, and C1s were used for data collection. Charge referencing was performed against adventitious carbon (C1s at 284.8 eV). Peak deconvolution and analysis were carried out using Thermo Avantage v5.9921 software. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation CO2 hydrogenation experiments were carried out in a stainless-steel 1/4" 316 stainless steel fix-bed reactor tube contained within 12″ house-made aluminum blocks that are heated by two 550 W Chromalox cartridge heaters. For each experiment, quartz wool was placed in the bottom of the reactor, then 3 g inert silicon carbide beads (Sigma-Aldrich, 200 mesh size) was added, then about 120 mg of the pelletized and sieved (425 −125 µm) catalyst was introduced, and finally 4 g of SiC was added on top. Thus, the catalyst bed was located between two beds of inert silicon carbide beads. A cylinder with 10% CO2, 33% H2 and balance N2 ± 2% (Mathenson) was used as the feed. Initially, a low-pressure tank was filled with the feed gas cylinder to a pressure of 400 psi. Then, a Maximator gas booster (DL-30–1) was used to compress the gases to the desired high pressure followed by storage in a high-pressure tank (∼2300 psi). From there, the reactor inlet flow rate was controlled using a mass flow controler (MFC) (Brooks Instruments). The pressure within the reactor was controlled by a backpressure regulator (26–1700) coupled with an electronic regulator (ER3000). Prior to all the CO2 hydrogenation experiments, the catalysts were in situ reduced at 400 °C and atmospheric pressure with 20% H2/N2 for 2 h. Then, the reactor was cooled to the desired temperature (240, 260, or 280 °C) and pressurized to 620 psi. The flowrate to the reactor from the high-pressure tanks was adjusted to the desired WHSV, between 3600 and 32,400 mL/gcat/h. The composition flowing from the outlet of the reactor was analyzed by an on-line 7890 Agilent gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with two TCD and one FID detectors. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of NiGa/ZrxCey catalysts Table 1 presents the structural properties of the synthesized NiGa/ZrxCey catalysts. The BET surface area increases with the addition of CeO2 with a maximum of 65 m2/g for the Zr3Ce7 support, and then decreases for pure CeO2, which is consistent with other Zr-Ce supports prepared by co-precipitation in literature [30,31]. The BET surface area for the pelletized and sieved NiGa/ZrxCey catalysts with particle sizes between 125 and 425 µm decrease compared to the as-prepared supports; this is related to preparation of the pellets. Like the bare supports, mixed oxides have a higher BET area than the pure supports. The NiGa particle size was estimated from CO chemisorption using a stoichiometry factor of 1, which agrees with the CO-DRIFTS reported by Rasteiro et. al. [26] in which it was evidenced that CO mainly bonds linearly to the NiGa alloy particle over NiGa/ZrO2 and NiGa/CeO2 catalysts. It is observed that smaller particle sizes were obtained for the Zr-Ce supports, as opposed to the pure ones, except for the Zr7Ce3 support, which had larger particle size than pure CeO2. It can be noted that dispersion obtained for these catalysts is lower compared to the dispersion reported for Cu/ZrO2-CeO2 catalysts in the literature, which is typically between 6% and 22% [30,33]. Fig. 1 a presents the XRD patterns for all reduced and passivated NiGa/ZrxCey catalysts. Neither Ni, NiO or Ga2O3 diffraction peaks were observed. However, due to the complexity of Ni-Ga system, with the NiGa phase diagram featuring up to 9 different phases, under reduction conditions (10% H2/Ar and 700 °C), different phases can be formed [34]. The observed diffraction peak at 43° indicates the formation of a NiGa alloy after reduction. This peak could be attributed to both α-Ni3Ga (43.8°) and δ-Ni5Ga3 (43.3°) [35]. Rietveld refinement fitting was performed to estimate the relative percentage of the NiGa alloy phases ( Table 2) identified on the catalyst. It was found that the Zr-rich catalysts i.e., ZrO2, Zr7Ce3, and Zr5Ce5 have a larger amount of the α-Ni3Ga phase compared to the Ce-rich catalysts, with Zr7Ce3 having the most (36%). Hejral et al. also reported the coexistence of the α-Ni3Ga and δ-Ni5Ga3 phases in a NiGa/SiO2 catalyst during in situ XRD experiments under H2 at temperatures above 500 °C [35]. Other potential NiGa peaks overlapped with the support diffraction peaks. The formation of the NiGa alloy over the ZrxCey supports was also observed by STEM-EDS ( Fig. 2 and Fig. S1). For the ZrO2 supported catalyst, both monoclinic (m) and tetragonal (t) phases were identified. With the addition of CeO2, the m-ZrO2 peaks disappeared (Fig. 1b and Fig. S2), which suggests that addition of Ce prevents the formation of this phase. Moreover, the t-ZrO2 diffraction peak at 30.5° shifts to a lower angle, indicating the incorporation of Ce4+ in the ZrO2 lattice, forming a solid solution [30,36]. Additionally with increasing Ce content, cubic CeO2 diffraction peaks at 28.5° and 33° intensity increase, indicating a shift from a Zr-rich to a Ce-rich solid solution. For the Zr7Ce3 support, the CeO2 diffraction peak shifts from 28.5° to 28.9° and appears as a shoulder adjacent to the t-ZrO2 peak at 30.2°. Similarly, the t-ZrO2 diffraction peak shifts from 30.5° to 29.8° and appears as a shoulder in the Zr3Ce7 catalyst. For the Zr5Ce5 support, shifted peaks of t-ZrO2 (30°) and c-CeO2 (28.9°) have the similar intensity, suggesting the coexistence of both, Zr-rich and Ce-rich solid solutions [37]. The formation of solid solutions by incorporations of Ce4+ or Zr4+ creates defects in the crystal structure, which has been reported to promote the formation of Ov [29,33]. Phase quantification was performed through Rietveld refinement of the support XRD patterns (Table 2 and Fig. S2), for the ZrO2 support about 74% corresponds to the tetragonal polymorph and 26% to the monoclinic phase. For all the ZrxCey supports, crystalline phase quantification of t-ZrO2 and c-CeO2 from Rietveld analysis is consistent with the synthesis stoichiometric ratios. Fig. 3 presents the H2-TPR profiles for the supports (Fig. 3 a) and NiGa catalysts (Fig. 3 b). For the ZrO2 support, two small peaks at 420 and 600 °C were observed. Even though some authors have reported ZrO2 to be non-reducible [30,38], these reduction peaks can be related to reduction of coordinatively unsaturated Zr4+ species at the surface of ZrO2, and coordinatively saturated Zr4+ at surface terraces or in the bulk of ZrO2, respectively [39–41]. With the addition of Ce, a high intensity peak between 400 and 500 °C appears and shifts from 470 °C to 420 °C with increasing Ce content. This peak has been ascribed to the surface reduction of Ce4+ and Zr4+ [30,39]. The shift to lower reduction temperatures indicates that the support can be reduced easily due to an increase in oxygen mobility associated with crystal defects created during the formation of the solid solution, as evidenced by XRD. A second peak between 600 and 700 °C shifts from 624 °C to 710 °C and increases in intensity with increasing Ce content. This peak is associated with the reduction of bulk CeO2 [28,30]. Reduction of Zr4+ and Ce4+ surface species is accompanied with the generation of Ov, which can activate CO2 [31]. Fig. 3 b shows the H2-TPR profile for the NiGa/ZrxCey catalysts, where multiple peaks between 200 and 600 °C related to the reduction of NiO, Ga2O3, ZrO2, and CeO2 were observed. A NiGa/SiO2 catalyst is included as a reference, and for this material a first reduction peak at 280 °C, related to reduction of NiO, was detected. Additional peaks occurred at 490 °C and 650 °C, related to the formation of the α-Ni3Ga and δ-Ni5Ga3 phases, respectively. For the ZrO2, Zr5Ce5, Zr3Ce7, and CeO2 supported catalysts, reduction peaks shifted to lower temperatures. For example, the NiO reduction peak shifted from 283 °C to 270 °C and 260 °C, respectively, for the ZrO2 and Zr5Ce5 supported catalysts and to 240 °C for the Zr3Ce7 and CeO2 supported catalysts. Moreover, the peaks related to the formation of the δ-Ni5Ga3 phase also shifted from 650 °C to 570 °C for ZrO2 and to 430 °C for the Zr5Ce5, Zr3Ce7, and CeO2 supported catalysts. This reduction in the peak’s temperature could be related to the increase in oxygen mobility, which increases with the content of CeO2.[26,30] However, the Zr7Ce3 supported catalyst exhibited a different behavior; despite the addition of CeO2, the reduction peaks appeared at a higher temperature than the peaks of the ZrO2 supported catalyst. This may be related to the different ZrO2 phases that are present in the ZrO2 and the Zr7Ce3 supported materials. The ZrO2 catalyst has a mixture of monoclinic and tetragonal phases, as evidenced by XRD, while the Zr7Ce3 catalyst has only the tetragonal phase. For Cu-based and Ni-based catalysts, it has been reported that the ZrO2 phase can influence the reduction temperature of CuO or NiO species, with t-ZrO2 having higher reduction temperatures than the m-ZrO2 [42,43]. Thus, the H2-TPR profiles indicate the presence of metal-support interactions, with Ov, generated by addition of CeO2, and the ZrO2 crystalline phase being the principal properties influencing the formation of the NiGa alloy. Both, the ZrO2 phase and Ov concentration have been reported to influence the basicity of the catalyst and the activation of CO2. For example, the monoclinic phase of ZrO2 has been reported to have stronger Lewis basicity of O2- anions, compared to the tetragonal polymorph, resulting superior CO2 adsorption capacity [44–47]. Similarly, formation of Ov has been reported to increase the concentration of basic sites [28]. To this end, the basicity of the NiGa/ZrxCey catalysts was studied by CO2-TPD ( Fig. 4). The CO2 TPD profiles were deconvoluted into 3 peaks using a gaussian function, representing weak, moderate, and strong basic sites. Weak sites are those at about 80 °C, moderate at about 150 °C, and strong sites at 250 °C. Weak base sites are related to surface hydroxyl species, moderate sites related to metal–oxygen pairs, and strong basic sites attributed to lowly coordinated O2– species, or oxygen defects [30,33]. The highest concentration of basic sites was obtained for the Zr5Ce5 and Zr3Ce7 supported catalysts (Fig. S3), which can be attributed to the formation of Zr-Ce solid solutions, as evidenced by XRD. Additionally, the increase in basic sites can also be correlated with the formation of Ov, as evidenced by XRD and XPS analysis ( Fig. 5) in the next section. However, despite the increase in Ov for the Zr-rich catalysts (i.e. Zr8Ce2 and Zr7Ce3), these materials had fewer basic sites than the ZrO2 supported catalyst (Fig. S3). This suggests that for the NiGa alloy-based catalysts at high Zr/Ce ratios, the Ov introduced by the formation of solid solutions is not the only factor that influences the basicity of the support, and the phase of ZrO2 is also a factor. Fig. 5 presents XPS spectra of the O1s (a), Ce3d (b), and Zr3d (c) regions for all the reduced and passivated NiGa/ZrxCey catalysts. O1s spectra were deconvoluted to 3 different peaks related to lattice O (OL) between 529 and 528 eV. These peaks shift to lower binding energies (BE) with increasing CeO2 content, since the CeO2 OL BE is lower than that of ZrO2. The lowest BE at 528.5 was observed for the Zr3Ce7 supported catalysts, which suggests a greater interaction between Zr and Ce in that solid solution [29]. The second peak at ∼ 531 eV can be related to mobile O of hydroxyl or carbonate species (OH-/CO3 2-) adsorbed on Ov. This peak has been used in the literature to estimate the Ov concentration on the catalyst surface [26,29,30,36]. Addition of CeO2 results in higher Ov content ( Table 3), which can be related to the formation of Zr-Ce solid solutions but also to the increase in the content of reducible CeO2. Finally, a third peak at ∼532 eV related to O in surface adsorbed water also appeared [26,33,48]. From the deconvolution of the Ce3d spectra, as shown in Fig. 5 b, coexistence of both Ce3+ and Ce4+ was observed. Peaks at BE centered at ∼ 880 and 885 eV correspond to Ce3+ 3d5/2 and peaks at ∼ 882, 888 and 898 eV corresponds to Ce4+ 3d5/2 (Table S1). Fig. 5 c presents Zr3d spectra for all the catalysts, with the peak at lower BE corresponding to Zr3d5/2. For the ZrO2 supported catalyst, this peak appears at 182.2 eV, characteristic of ZrO2. With the addition of Ce, this peak shifts to lower binding energies, indicating the presence of partially reduced Zr cations in the crystal structure, with the lowest BE at 180.5 eV for the Zr3Ce7 supported catalyst. This also confirms the formation of Ov on the NiGa/ZrxCey catalyst with the addition of Ce [36]. Moreover, while surface XPS quantification shows that the catalyst surface could be either Zr (Zr5Ce5 and Zr3Ce7) or Ce rich (Zr7Ce3), the calculated Zr/Ce ratios agree with the targeted synthesis composition in all cases (Table 3), which was also evidenced by Rietveld analysis (Table 2). From the Ni2p3 and Ga2p3 XPS (Fig. S3 and Table S1) deconvolution, it was found that the surface metallic loading agrees with the 20% value targeted from synthesis (Table 3). However, it was found that the surface Ni/Ga ratio is lower, indicating a Ga-rich surface. This was also evidenced by Gallo et.al [49] and Hejral et.al. [35]. These studies suggested the formation of a Ga2O3 shell around a Ni5Ga3 alloy on a reduced and passivated NiGa/SiO2 catalyst based on high resolution TEM and XPS depth profiles. 3.2 Catalytic performance Fig. 6 presents the CO2 conversion (a) and product selectivity (b) data as a function of temperature for all the NiGa/ZrxCey catalysts. An increase in temperature results in higher CO2 conversion (Fig. 6 a) but lower MeOH selectivity (Fig. 6 b) for all the ZrxCey supported catalysts. CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is an exothermic reaction, while the RWGS reaction is endothermic; thus, at higher temperatures the formation of CO is thermodynamically favored over MeOH formation [50]. The data show that CO2 conversion increases with an increase in CeO2 content ( Fig. 7), except for the ZrO2 and Zr7Ce3 cases, where ZrO2 has a higher CO2 conversion. The increase in CO2 conversion with Ce content can be related to the increase in Ov and basic sites, which may serve as an adsorption site for CO2. Rasteiro et al. reported the adsorption of CO2 as monodentate carbonates over NiGa/ZrO2, and NiGa/CeO2 catalyst through in situ DRIFTS experiments [26]. Similarly, Wang et al. found an increasing intensity of carbonate bands during in situ DRIFTS CO2 adsorption experiments over a Cu/ZrO2 catalyst with increasing Ov content, achieved by varying the calcination temperature [48]. However, Wang et al. reported a higher CO2 conversion over Cu/ZrO2 (12%) than over Cu/CeO2 (10%), despite the finding that the CeO2 supported catalyst had a higher Ov fraction (0.37 vs. 0.22). The authors attributed this to the larger amount of hydroxyl groups on the ZrO2 support, which was a combination of m-ZrO2 and t-ZrO2. It has been reported that m-ZrO2 has a higher concentration of hydroxyl groups compared to t-ZrO2 [44,51]. Thus, the presence of hydroxyl groups favors CO2 adsorption as bicarbonate species, which favors CO2 conversion over this crystalline phase. However, MeOH selectivity decreased with increasing Ce content (Fig. 7) [50,51]. Interestingly, over all the catalysts containing ZrO2 domains, CH4 was observed at 280 °C, which could be related to the coexistence of the Ni-rich, α-Ni3Ga phase with the Ni5Ga3 phase. It is well known that Ni is a highly active catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to CH4 [52]. Moreover, CH4 activity over the α-Ni3Ga phase was also evidenced by Hejral et al. over a Ni3Ga/SiO2 synthesized by the reverse-micelle method [35]. Fig. 6 c presents the MeOH selectivity vs. CO2 conversion for all the catalysts, including NiGa/SiO2 as a reference, since silica is the most common support reported in the literature for the NiGa alloy [23,35,53]. Conversions within a tight window were achieved by varying the WHSV from 3600 to 32,400 mL/gcat/h to allow for comparison of activity and selectivity at a common conversion range. It can be observed that at a CO2 conversion of about 3.5–4%, all the ZrxCey catalysts are more selective towards MeOH (40%) than the SiO2 supported catalyst (20%), especially the Ce-rich catalysts. This indicates the participation of the support during CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. For the Zr-rich catalyst, the MeOH selectivity was constant at all the WSHVs tested; this was also observed by Rasteiro et al. for a NiGa/ZrO2 catalyst [26]. On the contrary, for the Ce-rich catalysts, i.e Zr5Ce5, Zr3Ce7, and CeO2, there was a tradeoff between CO2 conversion and MeOH selectivity that is related to the production of CO through the RWGS at higher CO2 conversions and higher residence times. Despite the trade-off between CO2 conversion and MeOH selectivity, the ZrxCey catalysts had a higher MeOH space time yield (STY) than the SiO2-supported catalyst (Fig. 6 d), with Zr5Ce5 having the highest MeOH STY. In comparison with other NiGa and Zr-Ce containing catalysts reported in the literature [26,30,33,35,54,55] ( Table 4), the data show that using Zr-Ce solid solutions can improve MeOH selectivity to about 40–50% compared to SiO2, ZrO2 or CeO2 supports. However, compared to the Cu/Zr-Ce catalysts, the NiGa/ZrxCey catalysts reported in this study have lower CO2 conversion (2–5% vs 5–10%) and MeOH selectivity (40–50% vs. 60–90%). One reason for this could be the lower dispersion of the NiGa alloys compared (Table 1) to those for the Cu-based catalysts. [30,33,55]. For Cu based catalysts supported over ZrO2-CeO2, the catalytic performance has been attributed to the content of Ov, metallic surface area (Sm), metal dispersion (D) and concentration of basic sites (BS) [22,27,33,38,55]. To analyze the relation between catalyst properties and MeOH productivity, two more supports were prepared (Zr8Ce2 and Zr4Ce6) and evaluated. The properties of these materials are presented in Fig. S4 and the catalytic activity was evaluated at 260 °C, 600 psi and 7200 mL/gcat/h. Fig. 8 presents MeOH STY as a function of several factors, including the number of moderate basic sites (BS), oxygen vacancies (Ov), the surface metallic area (Sm) and the related metallic dispersion (D%). The strongest linear relationship was found for the moderate BS with a R2 of 0.86, while the R2 for weak and strong BSwas only 0.6 (Fig. S5); this indicates that CO2 adsorption and hydrogenation to MeOH follows the Sabatier principle, in which the moderate strength BS can activate CO2, but the binding strength is not high enough to prevent the hydrogenation of adsorbed intermediates and desorption of the products [26]. A larger concentration of BS was obtained for the Ce-rich mixed supports, i.e., Zr5Ce5, Zr4Ce6, Zr3Ce7, which increases the CO2 adsorption over these materials, leading to higher CO2 conversions and thus higher MeOH STY (Fig. 8 a). CO2 hydrogenation to MeOH over ZrO2-CeO2 containing catalysts, such as Cu/Zr-Ce, has been reported to follow the formate (HCOO*) pathway with two active sites, one for H2 activation (the metallic domain, either Cu0, Cuδ+ at the interface, or NiGa alloy) and one for CO2 activation (Ov on the Zr-Ce support) ( Scheme 1). For this pathway, it has been reported that the stability of the HxCOO* intermediates determines the product selectivity [20,21]. Weak adsorption of these intermediates results in its dissociation and increased CO selectivity. On the contrary, strong adsorption results in saturation of the BS or Ov, which leads to CO2 adsorption on the metallic domain, also resulting in increased CO selectivity [26,38]. In this regard, BS or Ov could serve to tune the stability of the key intermediates and therefore the product selectivity. Wang et al. identified through in situ DRIFTS that the rate determining step (RDS) over a Cu/Zr-Ce catalyst changes with respect the Zr:Ce ratio. For the Zr-rich catalysts, they proposed that the RDS is the activation of CO2 as HCOO* and its accumulation, while for the Ce-rich catalysts the RDS is the hydrogenation of HCOO* species to HxCOO* [33]. Thus, the Zr:Ce influences the RDS, which could explain the higher MeOH STY obtained over the mixed Zr-Ce supports compared to the pure ZrO2 or CeO2, for both the NiGa system (Fig. 6d) and the Cu systems found in the literature [19,27,30,31,33,55]. Another important factor influencing catalytic activity is the H2 activation over the Cu domain. For that reason, the high activity of Cu/Zr-Ce catalysts have also been attributed to high Cu dispersion (5–10%) and small particle sizes (∼ 10 nm) [27,33]. In the case of the NiGa alloy, the metal domains could be an active site for both H2 activation and CO2 hydrogenation ( Scheme 2) [23,25,26]. Rasteiro et al. reported from in situ DRIFTS experiments that bare ZrO2 and CeO2 did not exhibit catalytic activity towards MeOH, despite observing carbonate intermediates from adsorption of CO2. From these experiments and DFT calculations, they proposed that over NiGa/ZrO2, H2 is activated on the NiGa domain and hydrogenation of HCOO intermediates occurs simultaneously over the NiGa alloy (Scheme 2) and over the alloy-ZrO2 interphase (Scheme 1), which resulted in higher MeOH STY than NiGa/SiO2 and NiGa/CeO2. For all the ZrxCey supports, the NiGa D and Sm, are similar, with small changes between 0.1% and 0.8% and 2–6 m2/gcat, respectively. Thus, H2 activation is expected to be similar for all the materials, resulting in similar MeOH selectivity at similar CO2 conversions (Fig. 6 c). However, for MeOH STY as function of the D and Sm (Fig. 8 c,d), two groups can be observed, the Zr-rich and the Ce-rich supports, within these two groups the MeOH STY appeared independent of the D and Sm. This suggests the presence of alloy-support interactions, indicating that CO2 hydrogenation can occur following the Scheme 1 reaction pathway, with the alloy-support as an active site. Moreover, similar to the Cu-based catalysts, for the NiGa alloy system, enhanced MeOH STY can be achieved by introducing BS and Ov in the support, and they can be tuned by modifying the Zr:Ce ratio. The highest MeOH productivity was obtained for the Ce-rich solid solutions from Zr5Ce5 to Zr3Ce7). The lower selectivity obtained over all the NiGa/ZrxCey catalysts compared to the NiGa/SiO2 catalyst might be related to a decrease in MeOH formation rate over the NiGa alloy due to the larger particle sizes obtained over the ZrxCey supports. 4 Conclusions CO2 hydrogenation to methanol was evaluated over a NiGa-based catalyst using ZrxCey solid solutions as supports. Compared to the NiGa/SiO2 reference catalyst, all the ZrxCey exhibited higher MeOH STY at 260 °C, 600 psi, and 7200 mL/gcat/h, with the highest for the NiGa/Zr5Ce5 catalyst. CO2 conversion of 2.7% and MeOH selectivity of 47% were achieved over this catalyst. The Zr:Ce ratio affected the catalyst properties such as the ZrO2 crystalline phase, number of basic sites and concentration of Ov. Addition of CeO2 prevents the formation of monoclinic ZrO2. It was found that at high Zr:Ce ratios the crystalline structure of ZrO2 was more relevant to the catalytic activity than the Ov introduced by the addition of CeO2. For equimolar and Ce-rich catalysts with the t-ZrO2 crystalline phase, basic sites and Ov were the key parameters influencing the MeOH activity. Similar relationships have been reported for the Cu/Zr-Ce catalysts, which suggest that the promotion effect of the Zr-Ce relies on the interphase between the metallic domain (Cu, or NiGa alloy) and the basic sites and Ov in the support. However, the different Cu/ZrxCey catalysts reported in literature have a higher CO2 conversion (∼10%) and MeOH selectivity (< 60%) than those obtained for the NiGa/ZrxCey in this work (max of 5% and 53%) which could be related to higher Cu dispersion, with typical values between (5–10%) and smaller particle sizes (6–10 nm). Thus, one of the limitations of this current study is the different particle sizes obtained across the different ZrxCey supports. Further understanding of the synergy between Ov, BS, Sm, and D could be achieved by loading same size NiGa nanoparticles on the different ZrxCey supports. This could be accomplished by using colloidal methods or reverse-micelle synthesis for preparation of NiGa nanoparticles that can be loaded on the ZrxCey supports. On the other hand, the specific role of basic sites could be explored by impregnation of the catalyst with alkali salts that will increase number of basic sites without significantly modifying other properties of the support. coredata.dc:description: NiGa alloy particles supported on CeO2, ZrO2 and ZrO2-CeO2 solid solutions are prepared, characterized, and utilized for hydrogenation of CO2 into methanol. The nature of the support, including the Zr:Ce ratio, affects the catalyst structure and properties such as the ZrO2 crystalline phase, number of basic sites and concentration of oxygen vacancies. At high Zr:Ce ratios, the crystalline structure of ZrO2 has more influence on the catalytic activity than the oxygen vacancies introduced by the addition of CeO2, with the pure ZrO2 having the highest methanol selectivity of 53% with a CO2 conversion of 2.1% at 260 °C and 600 psi. In the equimolar and Ce-rich catalysts with a tetragonal ZrO2 crystalline phase, basic sites, and oxygen vacancies are the parameters most influencing the methanol production. The highest methanol productivity was obtained for the Zr5Ce5 supported catalyst, with a selectivity of 46.8% and a CO2 conversion of 2.7%. Overall, the space time yield of methanol is shown to correlate linearly with the concentration of moderate basic sites. The catalysts possess low activity relative to comparable systems utilizing metallic Cu phases, in part due to low NiGa dispersions achieved using the synthetic methods employed here.
coredata.dc:title: CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over ceria-zirconia NiGa alloy catalysts
